author: Eliot Shorr-Parks | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Eagles' Josh Huff has praise for Giants' Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie, but 'he takes some plays off'
text:
Eagles' Josh Huff has praise for Giants' Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie, but 'he takes some plays off' NFL: New Orleans Saints at Philadelphia Eagles Oct 11, 2015; Philadelphia, PA, USA; Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver Josh Huff (13) dives into the end zone as he scores on a 41-yard touchdown catch against the New Orleans Saints during the second quarter at Lincoln Financial Field. Mandatory Credit: Eric Hartline-USA TODAY Sports (Eric Hartline) Comments 
PHILADELPHIA -- Eagles second-year receiver Josh Huff is coming off of the best game of his career , catching five passes for 78 yards and a touchdown against the New Orleans Saints. 
This Monday night, Huff is hoping to have another strong showing -- and it seems like he is confident he can make it happen. 
Speaking at his locker, Huff gave his assessment of the New York Giants' secondary, which the Eagles will face this Monday in a must-win game at Lincoln Financial Field . 
Although he had some praise for Giants cornerback Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie, Huff also pointed out a flaw he sees in the cornerback's game. 
"If he is locked in once he gets going, once the game starts, he is pretty much one of the better corners in the league," Huff said. "But he takes some plays off, and when he takes some of those plays off, I'm going to try to bring it to him and let him know it's going to be a long day for him." 
Huff also had a brutally honest assessment of rookie Landon Collins , the Giants' first-round pick who has started five games for the Giants. 
"I know they have a rookie in the backend at safety. He is a down in the box guy. Not a real good cover guy with man," Huff said. "But he can come down and hit, tackle very well. They all, at sometimes, get lost in coverage, I would say. But they are very fundamentally strong." BRADFORD: Report card from win over Saints 
The secondary has been an issue for the Giants this season, as they are currently dead last against the pass in the NFL, giving up an average of 304.2 yards per game. 
If Huff is correct in his assessment, and the Eagles are able to take advantage of a Rodgers-Cromartie or Collins, quarterback Sam Bradford and the team's passing attack could be in for a big night. 
The Eagles are already coming off of their best offensive showing of the season, putting up 39 points and 519 yards of total offense. 
Being able to duplicate that showing on Monday night would be huge, considering it is very possible that the winner will end up in first place in the NFC East heading into Week 7. 
Whether they can do it remains to be seen, but listening to Huff, at least one member of the offense seems confident they can. THE NO-HUDDLE SHOW: Mega Eagles-Giants MNF preview
